IRIS COMPUTERS LIMITED Versus 399 Appellant; ASKARI INFOTECH PRIVATE LIMITED AND OTHERS Respondents. Criminal Appeal No. 250 of 20l3t, decided on February 6, 2013 A. Criminal Procedure Code, 1973 - Ss. 203, 204, 200, 202 and 482 - Recall of process once issued - Held, impermissible - Remedy available once process is issued - Explained - Complaint under S. 200 CrPC - Magistrate being satisfied that there existed material to proceed against accused and issuing process - Once process is issued and accused appears, Magistrate cannot go back to previous stage to dismiss/return complaint and to recall his issuance of process - Emphasised - No inherent powers for Magistrate under CrPC to review his earlier orders - If Magistrate erroneously issues process to accused, only remedy is under S. 482 CrPC - Process was issued to respondent-accused for offences punishable under S. 138, NI Act - After receipt of summons, respondent-accused filed application under Ss. 202, 203 and 245 CrPC contending lack of territorial jurisdiction of Magistrate - Accordingly, Magistrate returned complaint to be submitted before competent court - When High Court was approached against return of complaint, it affirmed view taken by Magistrate - Unsustainability of - Held, upon receipt of complaint under S. 200, Magistrate has to satisfy himself by conducting inquiry under Ss. 200 and 202, that there existed material to proceed against accused - If Magistrate is not satisfied, he can dismiss complaint under S. 203 otherwise can issue process under S. 204 - Accused cannot be heard till process issued under S. 204 is issued to him and he has no role in proceedings up to S. 203 - Once process is issued under S . 204 and accused appears, Magistrate cannot go back to stages between Sections 200 to 203 and review his own order as there is no such provision for review under CrPC - Once process is issued to accused under S. 204, he cannot be heard on invalidity or other legal aspects of stages between Ss. 200 to 203 already completed by Magistrate - Therefore, Magistrate cannot dismiss/return complaint on petition filed by accused - Even if order of Magistrate is vitiated or illegal , there is no provision under CrPC for review of orders passed - Thus, remedy under these conditions is to approach High Court under S. 482 CrPC but not Magistrate under S. 203 CrPC - On facts held , Magistrate erred in returning complaint to be submitted to competent court - Under these circumstances , High Court ought to have exercised its power under S . 482 CrPC - Hence, orders passed by High Court and Magistrate set aside, and complaint restored - Liberty granted to respondent-accused to question territorial jurisdiction before High Court- Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881, S. 138 t Arising out of SLP (Crl) No. 4984 of 2012. Criminal Procedure Code, 1973 - Ss. 200 to 204 and S. 482 and Ss. 397 to 401 - Complaint under S. 200 - No hearing to accused contemplated till process has been issued - Then too, remedy of accused thereagainst is not under S. 203 but under S. 482 C. Criminal Procedure Code, 1973 - S. 482 - No inherent power or review power of courts below High Court - Principles reiterated The appellant complainant had filed a complaint under Section 200, Criminal Procedure Code, 1973 against the respondent-accused for the offence punishable under Section 138 of the N egotiable Instruments Act, 1881. The Magistrate issued summons to the respondent-accused after being satisfied that there existed a prima facie case. After service of summons, the respondent- accused filed an application under Sections 202, 203 and 245 CrPC whereby they took the plea that the complaint was not maintainable due to lack of territorial jurisdiction. Considering this plea, the Magistrate returned the complaint to be filed before the competent court. This action of the Magistrate was challenged before the High Court by filing petition under Section 482 CrPC. The High Court affirmed the view taken by the Magistrate. Hence this appeal. Allowing the appeal, the Supreme Court Held: As far as recall of a process issued under Section 204 CrPC is concerned, CrPC does not contemplate or provide for any provision affording opportunity to the accused until the issuance of process to him under Section 204 CrPC. Before issuing summons under Section 204 CrPC, the Magistrate must be satisfied that there exists sufficient ground for proceeding with the complaint and a prima facie case is made out against the accused. The said satisfaction should be arrived at by conducting an inquiry as contemplated under Sections 200 and 202 CrPC . The first stage of dismissal of the complaint before the issuance of process arises under Section 203 CrPC, at which stage the accused has no role to play. Subsequent to issuance of process, the question of the accused approaching the court by making an application under Section 203 CrPC for dismissal of the complaint is impermissible because by then the stage of Section 203 CrPC is already over and the Magistrate has proceeded further to Section 204 stage. (Para 9) Adalat Prasad v. Rooplal Jindal, (2004) 7 SCC 338: 2004 SCC (Cri) 1927,followed Therefore, the crux of the matter rests into the existence of two different scenarios : the former involving only the complainant's role and the latter introducing the accused. The former constitutes cognizance of the offence on complaint, satisfaction reached by the Magistrate that a prima facie case is made out and thereafter, issuance of process to the accused. It is only after the aforesaid stages are complete, that the next stage is triggered enabling the accused to actively participate in the proceedings. The dismissal of complaint by the Magistrate under Section 203 CrPC evidently falls into the former stages of proceedings when the Magistrate has to base his opinion as to the existence of sufficient ground for proceeding towards the second stage on the statements of the complainant and the witnesses along with the result of the inquiry conducted under Section 202 CrPC. It is for obvious reasons that none of the former stages in CrPC provide for hearing the summoned accused, the said being only preliminary stages and the stage of hearing of the accused arising at subsequent stages provided for in the latter provisions in CrPC. Askari Infotech (P) Ltd. 1, dated 1-3-2012. The facts are: the appellant had filed a private complaint under Section 200 of the Code against the respondents for the offence punishable under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881 ("the Act" , for short). The learned Magistrate, by order dated 4-9-2010, took cognizance of the offence and the complaint was registered as CC No. 41505 of 2010. b Thereafter, the learned Magistrate, upon recording the evidence of the appellant and perusing through the documents produced along with the complaint, was satisfied that a prima facie case has been made out for the offence punishable under Section 138 of the Act and issued summons to the respondents by order dated 16-9-2010. 3. After service of summons, the respondents had filed an application c under Sections 202, 203 and 245 of the Code questioning the maintainability of the complaint due to lack of territorial jurisdiction of the court. The learned Magistrate, after hearing the parties, has allowed the said application and proceeded to recall his previous order issuing summons to the respondents and returned the complaint to the appellant, with a direction to present the complaint before the competent court by order dated 22-9-2011. d Being aggrieved by the aforesaid order, the appellant had filed a petition under Section 482 of the Code before the High Court. The High Court while concurring with the view taken by the learned Magistrate has rejected the said petition. 4. It is the correctness or otherwise of the aforesaid order passed by the High Court that is called in question by the appellant before us. e 5. The learned counsel appearing for the appellant would submit that the learned Magistrate was not justified in recalling the order issuing summons and thereafter, returning the complaint under Section 201 of the Code upon an application filed under Sections 202, 203 and 245 of the Code by the respondents. He would further submit that at the said stage of the proceedings the appropriate remedy to be sought, if the order of the learned Magistrate stands vitiated due to lack of territorial jurisdiction, is by filing of an application/petition under Section 482 and not under Section 203 of the Code. He would as sert that this aspect of the matter has not been noticed by f the High Court while rejecting the petition filed under Section 482 of the Code. In support of his submission, the learned counsel has placed reliance upon a three-Judge Bench decision of this Court in Adalat Prasad v. Rooplal g Jinda/2, wherein this Court has observed that the appropriate remedy to be sought in such stage of proceedings is by way of a petition under Section 482 of the Code. 6. We have heard the learned counsel for the parties to the lis and perused the judgment and order of the courts below. 8. The point that would fall for our consideration and decision is, b whether the learned Magistrate was justified in recalling the order passed by him issuing summons to the respondents upon an application made by them under Sections 202, 203 and 245 of the Code. 9. This Court has dealt with the question of recall of a process issued under Section 204 of the Code in Adalat Prasad case2 and opined that the Code does not contemplate or provide for any provision affording c opportunity to the accused until the issuance of process to him under Section 204. This Court has observed that before issuing summons under Section 204 of the Code the Magistrate must be satisfied that there exists sufficient ground for proceeding with the complaint and a prima facie case is made out against the accused. The said satisfaction should be arrived at by conducting an inquiry as contemplated under Sections 200 and 202 of the Code. The first d stage of dismissal of the complaint before the issuance of process arises under Section 203 of the Code, at which stage the accused has no role to play. Subsequent to issuance of process, the question of the accused approaching the court by making an application under Section 203 of the Code for dismissal of the complaint is impermissible because by then the stage of Section 203 is already over and the Magistrate has proceeded further e to Section 204 stage . 10. Therefore, the crux of the matter rests into the existence of two different scenarios; the former involving only the complainant's role and the latter introducing the accused. The former constitutes cognizance of the offence on complaint, satisfaction reached by the Magistrate that a prima facie case is made out and thereafter, issuance of process to the accused. It is f only after the aforesaid stages are complete; the next stage is triggered enabling the accused to actively participate in the proceedings. The dismissal of complaint by the Magistrate under Section 203 evidently falls into the former stages of proceedings when the Magistrate has to base his opinion as to the existence of sufficient ground for proceeding towards the second stage on the statements of the complainant and the witnesses along with the result g of the inquiry conducted under Section 202. It is for obvious reasons that none of the former stages in the Code provide for hearing the summoned accused, the said being only preliminary stages and the stage of hearing of the accused arising at subsequent stages provided for in the latter provisions in the Code. Having noticed the aforesaid, this Court in Adalat Prasad case 2 held a contrary view in respect of recalling of erroneous order of issuance of process from the earlier view taken by this Court in K.M. Mathew v. State of a Kerala 4 and opined that the scheme of the Code does not provide for review of order of issuance of process and prohibits interference by the accused at the interlocutory stage under Section 203. This Court, after overruling the view expressed by this Court in K.M. Mathew case 4 has stated as under: (Adalat Prasad case2 , SCC p. 343, para 15) "15. It is true that if a Magistrate takes cognizance of an offence, b issues process without there being any allegation against the accused or any material implicating the accused or in contravention of provisions of Sections 200 and 202, the order of the Magistrate may be vitiated, but then the relief an aggrieved accused can obtain at that stage is not by invoking Section 203 of the Code because the Criminal Procedure Code does not contemplate a review of an order. Hence in the absence of any c review power or inherent power with the subordinate criminal courts, the remedy lies in invoking Section 482 of the Code." 12. The aforesaid law laid down in Adalat Prasad case2 has been followed and reiterated by this Court in its subsequent decisions in Bholu Ram case3 , Subramanium Sethuraman v. State of Maharashtra 5 , N.K. Sharma v. Abhimanyu6 and Everest Advertising (P) Ltd. v. State (Govt. of d NCT of Delhi)7. In our view, the issue that we have raised for our consideration and decision is no more a debatable issue in view of what has been stated by a three-Judge Bench of this Court in Adalat Prasad2 and therefore, we are of the considered opinion that the High Court is not justified in rejecting the petition filed by the appellant under Section 482 of the Code. e 13. In view of the above, while setting aside the impugned judgment1 and order passed by the High Court and the orders passed by the learned Magistrate, we now direct the learned Magistrate to restore the complaint to its Board and proceed with the matter in accordance with law. However, we grant liberty to the respondents herein, if they so desire, to question the jurisdiction of the learned Magistrate, while issuing summons to them, before an appropriate court, including the High Court by filing a petition under Section 482 of the Code. We clarify that all the other contentions of both the parties are left open. 14. Ordered accordingly. 2 Adalat Prasad v.
